Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, § 19 and Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223A, § 3, as the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Middlesex County within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, § 19 and Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223A, § 3, as the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Middlesex County within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1,.proposition: Venue is proper in Somerville District Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8, because the cause of action arose in this judicial district and Defendant transacts business there.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010)).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard expressly abolished the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees in Massachusetts and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners/occupiers to all lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage even criticizes retaining different treatment for trespassers, underscoring that the core holding is a unified, reasonable-care standard for lawful entrants. Thus the case directly supports the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion, not shown in the user’s excerpt but central to Mounsey’s holding:] “We now hold that the common law distinction between invitees and licensees should be abolished… An occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable man in all the circumstances.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–708 (1973)). The concurrence you provided criticizes retaining a separate treatment for trespassers but accepts the core abolition of the licensee/invitee distinction.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010)).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that, under Massachusetts premises-liability law, a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, citing Mounsey as the foundational case. Papadopoulos’s main doctrinal move is to abolish the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and to apply this preexisting general duty of reasonable care to hazards from snow and ice, thereby affirming the proposition rather than creating it anew.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now discard the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, which had constituted an exception to the general rule of premises liability that a property owner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to use reasonable care to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances. See Mounsey, supra at 708.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: A reasonable operator of a grocery store would have discovered and remedied the hazard within a short period after notice, consistent with recognized standards of care (Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case concerns premises liability for a subway station stairway and focuses on whether there was sufficient circumstantial evidence that a foreign substance had been on a step long enough that the transit authority should have discovered and removed it. It does not discuss grocery stores, grocery store operators, or recognized industry standards for inspection and remediation times. Moreover, the court ultimately finds the evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant, which undercuts using this case as authority that a reasonable operator would have discovered and remedied the hazard within a short period after notice.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: "The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it... In summary, recovery has been denied to the plaintiff in the great majority of cases where he has attempted to establish the time element by circumstantial evidence consisting for the most part of a description of the foreign substance."

Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 343.proposition: - Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343, adopted by Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (premises liability standard of reasonable care).

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: - Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980) (landowners owe duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors).
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly adopts a general negligence standard for landowners/landlords toward lawful visitors. Building on Mounsey v. Ellard, the court states that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, and then extends that principle to landlords with respect to tenants’ guests on rented premises. Thus the case squarely supports the proposition that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “In Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973), we did away with the legal significance in tort of categories of licensee and invitee and held that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant. … Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: - Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) (liability where property owner had notice of hazard and failed to take reasonable steps).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Toubiana as a case imposing liability where a property owner had notice of a hazard and failed to take reasonable steps. In fact, the Massachusetts SJC held the opposite: even assuming the owner’s knowledge of the elevator’s condition and the risk, he had no duty to provide additional safeguards or warnings because the risk was obvious and the plaintiff’s use was not reasonably foreseeable. The court affirmed judgment for the defendant, finding no negligence, so the case does not support liability on the stated ground.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that… an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted. … Thus, the jury was unwarranted in inferring that an ordinarily prudent person… would have provided a solid elevator ceiling or a printed warning….”

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: - Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002) (foreseeability and duty).
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The decision directly analyzes whether the employer owed a duty to the murdered victim based on foreseeability of criminal acts by its employee. The court frames duty in terms of reasonable foreseeability, examines the employee’s criminal history and parole status, and concludes as a matter of law that no duty existed because harm to members of the public was not reasonably foreseeable in those circumstances. Thus the case is properly cited for the proposition concerning foreseeability and duty.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The most important consideration in determining whether a special relationship exists between a plaintiff and a defendant is whether the ‘defendant reasonably could foresee that he would be expected to take affirmative action to protect the plaintiff and could anticipate harm to the plaintiff from the failure to do so.’ … Here, the motion judge ruled that Titus & Bean did not have a duty to perform a background check on Kelley’s prior criminal acts because it was not reasonably foreseeable that he would attack a member of the public… Thus, in those circumstances, Titus & Bean could not have reasonably foreseen that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public, including the victim.”

Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.proposition: - Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (1994) (failure to warn or repair hazardous condition).
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.support_reasoning: The case rejects liability under these facts; it holds that a landowner has no duty to remove or sand a natural accumulation of snow and ice and that merely shoveling to expose naturally occurring ice does not create liability. The opinion explicitly concludes there was no actionable failure to remove, sand, or repair the hazardous icy condition because the ice was a natural accumulation that had not been changed from its natural state. Thus, it does not support a general proposition of liability for failure to warn of or repair a hazardous condition in this context; it does the opposite.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff also argues that, even if the actions by the town’s employees did not worsen the icy condition of the ramp, the town had an affirmative obligation to remove or sand the ice on the ramp. As has been discussed, however, the evidence indicates only that the ice on which the plaintiff fell was a natural accumulation. The situation is, therefore, governed by the Aylward decision, where there can be no liability because, as was said in Aylward, supra at 79, ‘naturally accumulated snow and ice on property does not per se constitute a defective condition.’… In conclusion, there was no evidence from which the jury could reasonably have concluded that an act or omission by the town changed the condition of the ice… Because such a conclusion is necessary in order to find liability, judgment for the town was required.”}

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: - Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (1995) (foreseeability test for proximate cause).
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether a landowner/possessor owes a duty to alter or seek alteration of an adjacent state highway, and on the scope of duties voluntarily assumed. Although the court briefly recites that negligence requires a duty and a breach proximately resulting in injury, it does not develop or apply a specific foreseeability test for proximate cause. The analysis turns on existence and scope of duty and control over the highway, not on a foreseeability standard for proximate causation, so this case is not proper authority for that proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, *743and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. See O’Gorman v. Antonio Rubinaccio & Sons, 408 Mass. 758, 760 (1990); Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989). Whether such a duty exists is a question of law. … In determining whether the defendant had a duty to be careful, we look to existing social values and customs, as well as to appropriate social policy.”

Patterson v. Christ Church in the City o.raw_text: Patterson v. Christ Church in the City of Boston, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 157 (2014)
Patterson v. Christ Church in the City o.proposition: - Patterson v. Christ Church in the City of Boston, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 157 (2014) (reasonable care of premises includes inspection).
Patterson v. Christ Church in the City o.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on application of the Massachusetts recreational use statute and whether the church charged a fee; it does not discuss the content of a landowner’s common-law duty of reasonable care, nor does it mention inspection obligations as part of premises liability. The court assumes, without analyzing, that plaintiffs have alleged negligent maintenance but resolves the case entirely on statutory immunity grounds. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for the proposition that reasonable care of premises includes inspection.
Patterson v. Christ Church in the City o.relevant_excerpt: “The Pattersons contend that Linda’s accident occurred because, in the poorly lit church, she was unable to discern the red riser from the red carpet. They allege that by maintaining the property in this defective condition, the defendants breached a duty of reasonable care owed to them. The recreational use statute… grants an exemption from liability for ordinary negligence… As a result, we are tasked with determining whether the defendants are excluded from the protections of the statute based on whether they ‘impose[d] a charge or fee’ under the statute.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute; Plaintiff bears no more than 50% fault).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B.proposition: B. Statutory interest and costs pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, §§ 6B and 6C;
